body:
I don't see that

```python
In [15]: df.hist(density=True)
Out[15]:
array([[<matplotlib.axes._subplots.AxesSubplot object at 0x115782ac8>]],
      dtype=object)
```

It doesn't look like you posted your pandas version info, so I'll assume that you're on an older version. LMK if not.
You are correct, I'm on 0.23.1 not 0.23.4. However when I updated to 0.23.4 the attribute error for density still remains.

Can you post a full traceback and the output of `pd.show_versions()` in the
original post?

Can you try on the 0.24.0 release candidate or master?

On Thu, Jan 24, 2019 at 7:43 AM John Aiken <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> You are correct, I'm on 0.23.1 not 0.23.4. However when I updated to
> 0.23.4 the attribute error for density still remains.
>
> â€”
> You are receiving this because you modified the open/close state.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub

>

http://matthewrocklin.com/blog/work/2018/02/28/minimal-bug-reports

Here is a minimally working example.

```
import pandas as pd

df = pd.DataFrame({'a':[1,2,3,4,5,6], 'b':[0,9,8,7,6,5,]})
df.hist(density=True)
```

```
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
AttributeError                            Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-3-eb03cdae17d5> in <module>
      3 
      4 df = pd.DataFrame({'a':[1,2,3,4,5,6], 'b':[0,9,8,7,6,5,]})
----> 5 df.hist(density=True)

~/anaconda3/envs/research/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pandas/plotting/_core.py in hist_frame(data, column, by, grid, xlabelsize, xrot, ylabelsize, yrot, ax, sharex, sharey, figsize, layout, bins, **kwds)
   2411     for i, col in enumerate(com._try_sort(data.columns)):
   2412         ax = _axes[i]
-> 2413         ax.hist(data[col].dropna().values, bins=bins, **kwds)
   2414         ax.set_title(col)
   2415         ax.grid(grid)

    884             ret = [_update_property(self, k, v)
--> 885                    for k, v in props.items()]

    887             self.eventson = store
```

I figured it out. It's because the matplotlib base was still on v2 and hadn't updated to version 3.
